column4: Includes mental handicap, learning disabled, but not dementia. It is not progressive and the delay should be present from birth.
SEIZURES, general abnormalities
Speech delay is common in developmental delay/mental retardation of all types. Use this latter feature rather than speech delay if the delay is more global.
A reduction in head circumference of greater than 2SD below the mean. Parental measurements must be taken into account.
BEHAVIOURAL PROBLEMS, general abnormalities
Severe impairment in social relationships, verbal and to some extent non-verbal communication, ritualistic and compulsive behaviour and defects of attention.
If this category is chosen all forms of 'short stature' are selected
Wide-set eyes. Measured as an interpupillary distance greater than 2SD of the mean.
Squint. Check cranial nerves for III, IV and VI nerve palsies. In some places (UK) it might be referred to by the patient as a 'cast'.
The topmost (superior) insertion of the ear is below an imaginary line drawn horizontally between the canthi of the eyes. The head must be in an upright position. A much over-diagnosed sign.
There is a loss of consciousness, followed by tonic contraction of all muscle groups, changing after 30-60 seconds to intermittent clonic jerking and then flaccidity.

Muscular hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle), often involving reduced muscle strength. Hypotonia is characterized by a diminished resistance to passive stretching.

These are folds which extend from the upper eyelid towards the medial canthi. They are common in neonates (epicanthus palpebralis) and Asians (epicanthus tarsalis). This entity includes epicanthus inversus which is an epicanthus extending from the medial canthi, downwards and laterally.
Floppiness not due to muscle disease or peripheral nerve disease, but whose origin is central (mostly in the brain).
The inability to concentrate for long on one activity before losing interest and moving on to the next.
Trichomegaly. Unsually long lashes which turn up.
A 'mongoloid slant' to the palpebral fissure.
Heart, general abnormalities
Note that this might be present unilaterally in 4% of the normal population and in a smaller percentage bilaterally.
The 8cm long interhemispheric structure joining the two halves of the brain. Includes absence or small.

column3: Patchy pigment of skin / cafe au lait spots
column4: These are large (>2.5cm in adults), light brown pigmented areas. In neurofibromatosis they have a smooth outline, but they might be ragged, as in McCune-Albright syndrome.
Most ears that appear prominent are large and rotated forwards (anteverted) - like Prince Charles.
The bridge is that part of the nose situated between the eyes. It might be difficult to assess in infancy when it is normally quite flat. If it remains so, or is particularly flat, use this category
A pencil-line upper lip
A high, often gothic shaped palate, in which it is difficult to see the top.
EEG, general abnormalities
The frontal hairline extends on to and down, the forehead.
That portion of the nose situated between the eyes (the bridge) seems wide.
Combative behaviour towards others and self. Might occur intermittently in an otherwise placid child, or be continuous and become a major handling problem.
A short head from back to front. If there is a craniosynostosis, it is mostly bi-coronal.
ATAXIA, general abnormalities
These are measured from top to bottom. Strictly speaking they should be above the 97th centile on the chart. Note that ears get larger with age.
Testes that have not descended into the scrotum (an empty scrotum).
An asymmetrical skull shape. Often, but not always, caused by unilateral fusion or one coronal suture
The anterior fontanelle is usually closed by 18 months.

Seizures are an intermittent `abnormality of the central nervous system` (FMA:HP:0002011) due to a sudden, excessive, disorderly discharge of cerebral neurons and characterized clinically by some combination of disturbance of sensation, loss of consciousness, impairment of psychic function, or convulsive movements. The term epilepsy is used to describe chronic, recurrent seizures.
Increase in ventricular size. If not gross, use with caution.
If this category is selected all forms of 'tallness' are chosen.
Use when you want to incorporate all the subdivisions listed below.
Thin from side to side and long from top to bottom.
A cleft (midline or otherwise) of the bony or soft roof of the oral cavity. Includes all shapes. If there is a cleft of the lip as well, use both in separate boxes.
Depression deformity of the sternum and anterior chest wall..
Also called athelia.
The birth of a baby of less than 37 weeks of gestational age.
Craniofacial dysmorphism
The term bossing means a protuberance, or round knob. A bossed forehead mostly has two prominences, divided by a shallow groove. For this feature any prominence will do (if not familial).
A malformed ear. A small ear (microtia) might be dysplastic in which case use both in the same box as either/or.

Defined as an ultrasonic measurement of axial length of less than 19mm in a child of 1 year, and less than 21mm in an adult (minus 2SD). Dysmorphologists usually diagnose this by inspection ("eyeballing!!")
Significant short-sightedness. Take family history because it might be unrelated to the syndrome under consideration.
Congenital or acquired. See elsewhere for III nerve palsy.
There are 3 confusing features. 1) Flat face 2) Mid facial hypoplasia 3) Malar region flat. Tend to use together in same box. The term 'dished out' face is also used in the literature.
Confusion over three terms used. 1) Mid-face hypoplasia 2) Flat face 3) Malar region flat. Use together in same box.
A subjective impression of a small jaw. Difficult in infancy and early childhood. Family background must be taken into account. The jaw often grows 'out' with age.
Also includes taurodontia (this includes gigantic roots as seen on X-rays). Also includes prominent central incisors.

Includes perimembranous (80%), muscular (5-20%), outlet (just below the pulmonary valve) and inlet (posterior and inferior to perimembranous defect). Don't be frightened to use 'Heart - general' as different defects even occur in the same family.
They are usually placed on the anterior axillary line and wide-spaced implies lateral displacement towards the mid-axilla.
Webbing of toes 2 and 3. Common in families, so use only if it isn't present in either parent.
There is mostly a brief loss of consciousness with little or no motor activity i.e. it is non-convulsive. Use in conjunction with the EEG entry 3-Hz spike and wave complexes.
A head circumference greater than 2 SD above the mean for age. Parental measurements must be taken into account.
Floppiness including that due to muscle disease or peripheral nerve disease. The origin is mostly central nervous system.
An increase of bodily fat out of proportion to the family pattern, resulting in an increase of weight above the 97th centile for age.
Below the 3rd centile for gestational age.
It might be better to use Vision - general'.
Eyebrows that meet in the middle.. Not always pathological.
An 'anti-mongoloid' slant to the palpebral fissure, which is normally horizontal.
Short from top to bottom. Measured from nasion to sub-nasion.
One side of the face is smaller or larger than the other. There are other codes if the asymmetry is more generalised. Use 'Find' and write 'asymmetry'.
A small mouth opening.
Mostly seen with thin upper lip, but use with discretion!

Normal times are (for milk teeth). 6 months - lower central incisors. 7 months - upper central incisors. 8 months - upper lateral incisors. 9 months - lower lateral incisors. 1 year - first molars. 18 months - canines. 2 years second molars
One or both feet are in-turned from the ankle downwards. It might be fixed and structural, or postural.
In this context, often due to immune changes.
Repetitive, purposeless, patterned and co-ordinated movements, like rocking, tongue protusion or hand wringing.
Overactive, non-stop, often purposeless behaviour, sometimes continuing to exhaustion of both patient and parents.
Includes sleeping too much, or too little, movements during sleep, sleep walking etc.
Involuntary micturition , mostly during sleep (bed wetting), occuring in the absence of a specific underlying cause.
A general category which incorporates all the categories under 'External ears general'.
Ears without the normal "geography" especially in the triangular fossa between the helix and the crus of the anti-helix. The ear is often 'cup' shaped (smooth and uninteresting).
An increased distance between the alae nasi.
The mouth droops open and tends to stay that way for long periods of time. Seen in profound hypotonia of any cause.
A lateral curvature of the spine.
Secundum ASD - the incomplete formation or incomplete fenestration of the septum primum covering the fossa ovalis. See elsewhere for septum primum defects.
A symptom rather than a sign!

Results from the failure of the intestine to return to the body cavity during development. It is midline, at the point of insertion of the umbilical cord. The contents are enclosed in a membranous sac. Intestine, liver pancreas, spleen may be present in the sac.
The urethral opening is on the underside of the penis.
There is fusion in the midline (inferiorly) resulting in the horse-shoe shape. In lateral fusion one pelvicalyceal system, crosses the midline to drain a portion of both kidneys.
An incurving - often seen in little finger. It may, or may not, be important.
The thumb seems short, but in essence it is inserted much too close to the radius (i.e., proximally).
Small, underdeveloped nails.
An inability to formulate and express words.
Also called salaam attacks, these are flexion (or occasionally extension) spasms causing the child to flex forward and abduct and extend the arms.
Occur between 3 months and 5 years and are triggered by a rising temperature. Most (but not all) are brief and uncomplicated.
Flat at the back. Seen in floppy children who lie continuously on their back. And in lambdoid craniosynostosis (bilateral), in which most of the posterior fossa is under-developed..
If there is generalised aplasia of the cerebellum add hemisphere (see below) in a separate box. The vermis is the ancient, midline structure of the cerebellum.

Lissencephaly means a smooth brain or agyria (an absence of fissures). The underlying defect is one of neuronal migration. Pachygyria is also a migration defect causing thickened and wide gyri. There is a separate entry 'neuronal migration defect' under 'Microscopic' for milder lesions and a separate entry for 'polymicrogyria'. Be flexible - use some, or all together.

This might be a clinical symptom. The sweat pores are best seen on the fingertips through a magnifying instrument with bright light (otoscope) when the lack of the normal glistening drops of fluid will be noted.
Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior.

Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence.
Double outlet right ventricle (DORV) is a type of ventriculoarterial connection in which both great vessels arise entirely or predominantly from the right ventricle.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy.
A sudden flexion, extension or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles which is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure.
Abnormality of coordination
Difficult to judge when anyone is abnormally thin. Use with caution and take the family pattern into account.
The hair feels on palpation unusually hard or rough.
Viewed with the head in an upright position, the ears are rotated backwards (posteriorly).
Any type of deafness. Useful when you are not sure.
Nystagmus - see NEUROLOGY / NYSTAGMUS
Mostly thick and bushy (as in one of the authors, MB). Not always pathological.
An elevation of the tip of the nose.
Mostly seen in generalised obesity (use if present). A moon face.
As in cleft lip and palate.
Macroglossia, as in Beckwith syndrome, due to an increase in bulk of the normal tongue tissue.

column3: Nuchal bleb / cystic hygroma of neck
column4: These are fluid filled cystic swellings, mostly at the back or side of the neck, but which might encircle the neck. They might have a single space, or be divided by septa into many chambers.

Closure occurs post-natally in two stages. Within 12 hours (after full-term), shortening, thickening and protrusion of the thickened intima and then within 2-3 weeks infolding of the endothelium etc. Isolated patency occurs in 1 in 2000 live births.
The presence of abdominal viscera in the inguinal canal ( the open communication of the peritoneal cavity with the diverticulum known as the processus vaginalis (the inguinal canal).
Differs from an omphalocele in that at most it contains a mid-gut loop but no viscera. Umbilical herniae are often seen in those of African origin, and are of no significance.
Be sure to differentiate from a concealed penis (concealed in fat). Less than 2cm at birth and less than 4cm before normal puberty.
Fluid in, and expansion of, the renal pelvis.
Short fingers
They give the feeling that you can move them (even temporarily dislocate them) in all directions.
Short and sometimes 'stubby'. The term brachymetaphalangy is used when both metacarpals and phlanges are short.
Anything the matter with the hip.
Bent, overlapping, curly toes.
An increased space between the first and second toes.
Mostly detected on neonatal screening.
A commonly inherited, uncomplicated feature. Check both parents before using it in a patient with a possible syndrome.
Use with codes on both sides of this age range in the same box.
Excluding apnoea (see above). It might be necessary to use this with asphyxia (see above).
Hyperactive tendon reflexes, often with increased tone and extensor plantar responses.
Chronically recurrent erythema, scaling, vesicles and crusts). Eczema means "boil over". Atopic dermatitis is used synonymously and means "not confined to one place".
Small or large (but discreet areas) of white depigmented skin.
Abnormal (retrograde) movement of urine from the bladder into ureters or kidneys related to inadequacy of the valvular mechanism at the ureterovesicular junction or other causes.
An abnormality in which the `mandible` (FMA:52748) is `mislocalised posteriorly` (PATO:0001922).
The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy.
The male foreskin cannot be fully retracted from the head of the penis.
Orofacial dyskinesia

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) manifests at age 2-3 years or by first grade at the latest. The main symptoms are distractibility, impulsivity, hyperactivity, and often trouble organizing tasks and projects, difficulty going to sleep, and social problems from being aggressive, loud, or impatient.

Impaired feeding performance of an infant as manifested by difficulties such as weak and ineffective sucking, brief bursts of sucking, and falling asleep during sucking. There may be difficulties with chewing or maintaining attention.
If this feature is used all categories of 'obesity' will be chosen
Proportionate implies that despite the short stature the relationship between the trunk length and limb length has not altered.
Often seen in conjunction with 'bossed forehead'. If so use both features in the same box. The origin (roots) of the frontal hair seems posteriorly displaced.
Broad from side to side.
A small forehead in its broadest meaning.
A difference in size between the two sides. If one is significantly smaller it might be better to use microtia.
These are pre-auricular hillocks, or nubbins of tissue. They are vestigeal remnants of the developing ear.
Small normal looking ears, but used by some for small dysplastic ears. Use the two together in the same box if in doubt.
It might be better to use 'deafness general' to pick up all types.
Used synonymously with middle ear deafness.
Try to avoid this in favour of (mostly) sensori-neural deafness.
The nerve itself is involved.
Use with caution as sensorineural or conductive deafness might be more appropriate.
The lobule is tilted upwards rather than hanging down.
Any abnormality seen mostly on imaging, or on electrophysiology.
A subjective observation of eyes that seem sunken in the skull.
Eyes too closely set. Measured as an interpupillay distance less than 2SD of the mean.
Lens opacities of all types
Pallor of the optic disk, with fewer than normal vessels on the surface. The pallor might initially be segmental (temporal) before becoming diffuse.
Long sighted. Might be incidental - ask family.
Anything wrong with the eyebrows.
Difficult to quantify. Sometimes seen in conjunction with sparse scalp hair.
The fissure is short in the horizontal plane i.e. from side to side.
The nostrils normally point slightly laterally. Anteverted nares point forwards, so that you can look directly into the nasal cavity.
This includes everything under face-general (click + to see what there is).
Small, but not triangular.
A broad forehead, and a small chin, with, the two sides of the triangle creating a small, delicate looking face. The head looks large (pseudo-hydrocephalus).
The normal symmetry of tooth eruption is distorted resulting in irregular positioning and crowding. Might be secondary to alterations in jaw structure (see under 'mouth/mandible').
A trident is a 3-pronged fish spear used by Neptune. A trident hairline has 3-forks pointing down the neck. Beware, it may be a normal feature.
The head seems to sit directly on the shoulders (or closer than normal to the shoulders).
A neck which seems overburdened with tissue.
The body of the vertebrae slopes forwards. It looks like a triangular wedge (from the side).
Narrow from side to side. If also hollowed out, use 'pectus excavatum' in same box with it.
The presence of fluid, including lipid-laden, milky chyle in the pleural cavity.
Posterior-lateral herniation (mostly through the foramen of Bochdalek) mostly without a membrane and often containing viscera.

Includes the term AV-canal defects and endocardial cushion defects. Occurs in 4-5% of congenital heart disease. It might be used with ASD and VSD or "Heart - general" in same box. Partial defects include primum ASD, inlet VSD defects, cleft of mitral leaflet and cleft septal tricuspid leaflet - so don't be too particular. There is a separate feature for "primum septal defects".
Includes hypertrophic and dilated cardiomyopathies.

A right aortic arch is a single arch that crosses over the right mainstem bronchus and passes to the right of the trachea. Note that it occurs in many patients with Fallot (use together). In double or duplicated aortic arch, both right and left aotic arches are present (one might be hypoplastic). They form a vascular ring around the trachea and oesophagus. Use "'Heart-general" liberally.

Includes valvular and supravalvular stenosis. Also includes peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis. Note that these lesions often occur with others. Be broad - use general features, or many individual features in the same box.
Extra nipples in the "milk line". Seen both normally and in some syndromes (also called polythelia)
Sometimes a manifestation of Hirschprung disease, or secondary to gross hypotonia. Use with caution .
Use in conjunction (same box) as abnormal function, to increase the yield.
A tumour-like mass of pale muscle, 3-5cmm long, situated at the pylorus. It seems to derive from the circular layer of fibers.
Onset of puberty before 9 years.
Any renal lesion.

In infantile polycystic disease the kidneys are enlarged. The renal cysts are visible on the surface and are formed by the ends of the ectatic collecting ducts. Do not use for 'cystic dysplastic' kidneys, or alternatively use with 'renal dysplasia' in the same box. In medullary cystic disease the cysts are mainly in the medulla. This is included here.
This includes meatal stenosis and in males congenital strictures in the prostatic urethra. It includes urethral diaphragms,
Thick, 'juicy', swollen-looking fingers - they may also be tapered.
Use in same box as hypoplastic, as it might difficult to distinguish between the two.
A broad, spatulate and sometimes deviated thumb.
Usually one limb is smaller than the other. There is a separate feature for 'hypertrophy of lower limb'
Also called knock knees. The child stands with knees together and feet apart.
Anything wrong with the feet.
There are deep furrows on the sole, often between the big and second toes or on the foot pad.
Long for age, mostly as judged by shoe size!
Often in conjunction with long feet. Narrow from side to side.
Less than 2.2mmol/l in the older child, and less than 2.8mmol/l in the well neonate.
Attacks of "stopping breathing".
From failure to respond spontaneously, or on command, to failure to respond to pain etc.
The seizure consists of tonic contractions without proceding to clonic jerking. The sudden contraction of large muscle groups might cause a child to be thrown to the ground.
Decreased cerebral perfusion, caused by low blood pressure and culminating in loss of consciousness.
A bulging (posteriorly) of the occiput.
A wide-based unsteady gait, titubation, an abnormal finger-nose test with increasing tremor as the nose or finger is reached.
Weakness of the legs, to a greater extent than that of the arms. Use with 'brisk reflexes'.
Loss or dimunition of peripheral appreciation of pin prick. "Is it sharp or blunt"?
These are discharges of spikes or sharp waves over a distinct area of the montage. Suggests localized pathology.
There are synchronous (bilateral) discharges. See elsewhere for spike and wave complexes.
Use if vermis is normal. If not, add vermis in separate box. Try, if dissatisfied, to use the two together as either/or.

Another result of a neuronal migration defect resulting in many, small gyri. There are separate entries for 'lissencephaly/pachygyria' and 'neuronal migration defects (mild), but be flexible, use in various combinations when necessary.
A fourth ventricle malformation characterised by atresia of the foramina of Luschka and Magendi and a cystic malformation of the midline cerebellar structures.
Skin, general abnormalities

These include, epidermal nevi, melanocytic nevi and pigmented nevi. Lentigines are small, brown or black, round lesions (1-2mm in diameter) darker , with more uniform pigmentation, than freckles (ephelides). See also codes for "Haemangiomas".
This term is used for a "port wine", "salmon patch" or any cutaneous vascular lesion consisting of a dense network of capillaries.
Abnormality of the testis
A condition in which the upper scrotal skin rises over the base of the penis.

`Hyperplasia` (MPATH:134) of the `gingiva` (FMA:59762, that is, a thickening of the soft tissue overlying the alveolar ridge. The degree of thickening ranges from involvement of the interdental papillae alone to gingival overgrowth covering the entire tooth crown.

Hydrocephalus is an active distension of the ventricular system of the brain resulting from inadequate passage of CSF from its point of production within the cerebral ventricles to its point of absorption into the systemic circulation.

Occipito-frontal (head) circumference (OFC) less than -3 standard deviations compared to appropriate, age matched, normal standards (Ross JJ, Frias JL 1977, PMID:9683597). Alternatively, decreased size of the `cranium` (FMA:46565).
Tall head relative to width and length.
Abnormal prominence of the `chin` (FMA:46495) related to `increased length` (PATO:0000573) of the `mandible` (FMA:52748).
Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border.
Bird-like facies
Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or apparently narrow intertemporal region (subjective).
`Developmental hypoplasia` (MPATH:10060) of the `mandible` (FMA:52748).
Distance between subnasale and pronasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased anterior protrusion of the nasal tip.
A form of astigmatism in which one meridian is hyperopic while the one at a right angle to it has no refractive error.

Reduced visual acuity that is uncorrectable by lenses in the absence of detectable anatomic defects in the eye or visual pathways. Ambylopia can result from visual deprivation during the critical period of development of visual abilities which lasts to about the age of 8 years. Thus, ambylopia can result from strabismus, anisometropia, or high hypermetropia in there is a failure to form a focused image in one or both eyes.
A condition characterized by pervasive dysphoric mood, loss of interests, and inability to experience pleasure.
Decreased subcutaneous fat
An anomaly of the `thumb`(FMA:24938).
Single umbilical artery (SUA) is the absence of one of the two umbilical arteries surrounding the fetal bladder and in the fetal umbilical cord.
Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70.
Mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 50-69.
Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.

A type of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) into the parenchyma of the `brain` (FMA:50801).
Inflammation of a joint.
`Increased pressure` (PATO:0001576) in the `portal vein` (FMA:66645).
Abnormality of the upper arm

column3: Autosomal dominant with variable expression and incomplete penetrance
column4: Autosomal dominant with variable expression and incomplete penetrance
Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.
An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.
`Increased size` (PATO:0000586) of the `heart` (FMA:7088).
Failure of the foramen ovale to seal postnatally, leaving a potential conduit between the left and right cardiac atria.
Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the aorta.
An abnormal reduction in numbers of all blood cell types (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets).
An abnormality of the process of `blood coagulation` (GO:0007596). That is, altered ability or inability of the blood to clot.
An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components.

Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement).

A type of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as rhythmically tapping the fingers on the knee, generally related to a cerebellar lesion.

Pulmonary hypertension is defined as a mean pulmonary artery pressure greater than 25 mm Hg during rest (normal level, 10 mm Hg) or greater than 30 mm Hg during exercise (normal level, 15 mm Hg), as determined with right heart catheterization.
Seizures with sudden, brief (< 100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal).
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring within the `skull` (FMA:46565).
Replacement of normal lung tissues are progressively replaced by fibroblasts and collagen.
A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected.
Red hair
Poor speech
An abnormality of the `cerebral cortex` (FMA:61830).
The presence of a high and narrow palate.
The presence of abnormally small extremities.
Abnormality of mitochondrial metabolism
Onset of signs or symptoms of disease between 28 days to one year of life.
Clinodactyly refers to a bending or curvature of the `fifth finger` (FMA:24949) in the radial direction (i.e., towards the 4th finger).
Increased body weight
Chronic inflammation of the bronchi.

column3: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
column4: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
Infantile encephalopathy
Ectropion of lower eyelids
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset.
Narrow palpebral fissure, unilateral

A failure of regression of the hyaloid vessel, which supplies the primary vitreous during embryogenesis and normally regresses in the third trimester of pregnancy, leading to a particular form of posterior cataract. This condition is known as Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV).
Pterygia affecting the neck.
`Syndactyly` (HP:0001159) with fusion of toes three and four.

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.

A kind of `ventriculomegaly` (HP:0002119) occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (pmid:16100637).
An abnormality of the concentration of `glucose` (CHEBI:17234) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).

A depression of the dorsum of the nose with loss of nasal tip support and definition, shortened (vertical) nasal length, overrotation of the nasal tip, and retrusion of the nasal spine and caudal septum.
Seizures characterized by impaired consciousness.
Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone.

Cerebral palsy describes a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitation, that are attributed to nonprogressive disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain. The motor disorders of cerebral palsy are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition, communication, and behaviour, by epilepsy, and by secondary musculoskeletal problems.
Abnormal eating behavior
An abnormality of the `tonsils` (FMA:9609).

The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand.
An abnormality of emotional behaviour.
If this category is chosen, all forms of muscular build are selected.
As judged by gestational age. See elsewhere for 'advanced bone-age' which might be present.

column3: Thin or slender build, general abnormalities
column4: If this feature is used all categories of 'thin' will be selected.

This is disproportionate short stature ie., the trunk is normal but the limbs are short. Note under 'upper' and 'lower' limbs, there are other categories of 'proportionate short arms' and' legs', etc.
Increase in height above 2SD, for age. The increase in height involves both the trunk and the limbs.

Encompasses all categories of thin hair. Difficult in very young children as hair growth is variable in speed and luxuriance. Beware in children, especially those with learning difficulties, who pull out their hair, or lose it by rubbing against the pillow.
Either generally sparse, or patches of sparse hair.
Fine or thin to the touch. Seen sometimes in conjunction with sparse depigmented hair. Use together when appropriate.

Pili torti refers to the twisting of hair through 180 degrees on its own axis. This gives a spangled or beaded appearance. This feature also includes abnormally (for the family) curly hair as in Noonan syndrome, although histologically the hair might be normal.
A double whorl, or an eccentrically placed whorl. Use with caution as normal variation is great.
Literally as if a cow had licked the frontal hair and it stayed in an upward sweep from the forehead.
Patchy area of hairiness. If there is an underlying pigmented, raised skin lesion (see under SKIN - 'pigmented'), use both in same box when necessary.
The glabella is the most prominent point in the plain between the eyebrows (the word means 'smooth part').
Sloping backwards from bottom to top. Often seen in cases of 'true microcephaly'. If that is the case use both features in the same box.
EARS
On palpation the ear is soft and floppy.
Where the lobule is attached posteriorly to the skin behind the ear.
Middle ear, general abnormalities
Bulging, prominent, exopthalmic eyes. Eyes which appear too big for the socket.

Hypoplasia of the anterior iris stroma, accompanied by strands which run from the iris to Schwalbe's line (the posterior limit of Descemet membrane) and posterior embryotoxin (abnormal thickening of Schwalbe's line).
In adulthood the diameter should be 11.7mm and this is attained by 2 years of age. Macrocornea is a diameter of > 13mm.
An absent eye although there is often a tiny cystic remnant. There might be a spectrum between anophthalmia and microphthalmia, so try using both in the same box if necessary.

column3: Optic disc and nerve, general abnormalities
column4: Anything wrong with nerve or disc.
An important marker for collagen disorders, but deceptive in young babies and easy to falsely diagnose if the baby is wearing blue. Take the baby to the window to view.
Includes all the features under 'Vision'
It is better to use a feature which indicates the cause - if known.
Unspecified abnormality. Might be better to use 'Vitreous - general'
EYES, ASSOCIATED STRUCTURES
Thickened, swollen, fluid filled.
There is a failure of the lacrimal system to connect to the nasal mucosa. The duct might be blocked, or is absent.
In the shape of an almond nut. Said to be typical of Prader-Willi syndrome, but common in any type of obesity and it is very non-specific.
Small eye openings. The aperture is reduced along all planes. In blepharospasm there is forceful, bilateral eye closure.
Wide from side to side. The fissure appears to disappear around the corner of the face.
Anything contained in the subdivisions viewed by clicking the +.
A raised bridge (that part of the nose between the eyes). The nose appears particularly straight with a high take off.
An alteration in shape. Flat or curved down.
FACE
A mid-line groove as in Kirk Douglas..
Mostly a midline cleft. Use in same box as 'cleft of the chin' when appropriate.
Might clinically present with prognathism. A jutting jaw.
The corners of the mouth normally end in the horizontal position.
The central area between the upper lip and nose. The philtral pillars with funnel in between are centrally placed.
A long area between the columella of the nose and margin of the upper lip.
Short area between columella and upper lip margin.
A featureless philtrum. A smooth philtrum.
Often a small V-shaped indentation in the mid-line.
Mostly a midline cleft. Might have the same significance as a cleft palate. Consider using them together in the same box.
Anything wrong with the tongue.

Excludes neonatal teeth, but the teeth erupt much faster than the norm which is: 6 months - lower central incisors. 7 months - upper central incisors. 8 months - upper lateral incisors. 9 months - lower lateral incisors. 12 months - first molars. 18 months - canines.
Use with care. Might or might not be significant. It usually is not.
The visible tooth - the crown - is covered by very hard calcified tissue- the enamel. An abnormality results in excessive wear and possible erosion down to gum level.
The teeth in upper and lower jaws do not close with any precision on one another.
This might be seen in conjunction with small teeth (use in same box when necessary). Also to be used for a wide gap between the central incisors (diastema).
Any of the following: slurring speech, staccato speech, stutter etc. It is an articulation defect.
A bent spine. Flexion angulation of the spine over many segments.
Literally meaning "bent backwards". Mostly seen in the lumbar region and it is an exaggeration of the normal hollowed out configuration in that area.

A closed spina bifida. One with a skin covering. Note separate features for 'sacral dimple' and under 'Back and Spine', - 'spinal dysraphism'. If appropriate use together in same box as this is a continuum.
Note that there is a feature 'early puberty in the female' under 'GENITALIA'.
Absent or small. Short clavicles might be felt, or seen, when they end in a knob.
Poor muscularisation of the diaphragm, results in a dome-shaped bulge into the thorax. The bulge is covered by peritoneum.
The pulmonary veins might connect to the right atrium. Also called TAPVC. (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connections), if all the veins connect anomalously, and PAPVC, if partially.
Occurs in 3-6% of congenital heart disease. Includes congenital bicuspid valve which may become stenotic and supra valvar aortic stenosis.
Rather use 'Heart - general'.
There is a continuum of anomalies from hypoplasia, of the aorta, aortic valve, mitral valve, to hypoplasia of the left ventricle and left atrium.
Might be an underlying mitral leaflet cleft. Mild incompetence is common in women.
See elsewhere for 'constrictive pericarditis'. A pericardial effusion is included here.
This includes 3 types: 1) Single left ventricle with or without an outlet infundibular chamber 2) Single right ventricle 3) Undifferentiated ventricle See also "hypoplastic left heart".
These include bronchogenic cysts (derived from the trachea or main bronchi), and alveolar cysts, or a combination.
A general category. Might think of rather using 'lung-general'.
A general category which includes, atresia, webs, stenoses, fistulae.
Anything wrong with the ribs.
An elevation of the scapula which might be hypoplastic. About 1/3 have a omo-vertebral bone (a bony/cartilaginous mass attaching the scapula to the spinous processes of the cervical vertebrae).
Anything wrong with the abdomen.

column3: Small bowel atresia / absence / obstruction / short
column4: Includes multiple obstructions or ileal or jejunal atresias. There is a separate code for 'duodenal atresia'.
Dysphagia - see CRANIAL NERVES
The normal rotation and fixation of the gut does not take place. The caecum might end up in the epigastrium to the left of the duodenum. Volvulus might occur.
Anything wrong with the anus.
Also includes "covered" anus and imperforate anus.
Anything wrong with the liver.
Any abnormality of the spleen.
By palpation or imaging.
Fluid filled scrotal sac.
There are measurements, but most dysmorphologists will assess visually and listen to the parents.
Underdevelopment of the scrotal sac, mostly secondary to the absence of a testis. Use in the same box in conjunction with "absent testis" or "undescended testis".
Urinary tract, general abnormalities
The bladder opens widely onto the surface of the abdomen. The mucosa of the pelvic urethra is exposed.
An absent (or near absent) kidney.
Ectopy is an abnormal positioning of the kidney. It might be pelvic or thoracic in its displacement. Supernumerary kidneys may have a separate ureter and kidney
Glomerulonephritis, nephronophthisis, etc.
Small, normal looking kidneys. There is a separate code for 'renal dysplasia'.
There is a separate code for 'bladder stones'. It might be better to use both in same box. Use this code for nephrocalcinosis.
Any tumour including nephroblastomatosis.
Absent, or dilated for whatever reason.
Use with caution as an X-ray might show a short humerus, or radius or ulna (see other codes for hypoplasia of those bones). Use together in the same box when necessary.
Small, malformed humerus.
An increased carrying angle at the elbow. This is normally greater in females than in males.
A small, poorly formed radius.
An absent, or short, malformed ulna.
Tiny, delicate hands.
Any abnormality of the larger creases of the palm. See below for single palmar crease.
An increase in the depth of the normal hand creases. Seen in chromosomal mosaicism or as the consequence of clenched hands or oedema in utero.
A wide category for any finger abnormality.
Often a large (huge) single finger, but all or some might be involved. Always compare with other hand.
The extra digits arise from the little finger side.
The fingers are swept to the radial side.
The term 'wind swept' is used to describe the deviation of the fingers (they seem blown to the ulnar side).
Anything wrong with the metacarpals.
Mostly in association with absence of elements of the fingers.
One or more is very rudimentary, or absent.
Seen alone or as part of radial aplasia.
Difficult feature - use together with hypoplastic thumb and make sure that the so-called shortness is not due to proximal placing.
Might be seen with underlying polydactyly (especially pre-axial). If very broad, an X-ray might be appropriate.
Might be a sign of a 'nail dystrophy'. If so use both in the same box. Mostly diagnosed (they break easily) on history.
An avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses and the femoral head. Better known as Legg-Calve-Perthe hip.
You might want to use this with hypoplasia (see above).
Under-developed or absent tibia.
A foot is flat when the medial side is too close to the ground, or the heel is unduly everted. Also called pes planus.
Feet that seem too big (shoe size is helpful).
Small for age (and shoe size if you are not a measurer).
Wide from side to side. A flat foot can look wide, so use with caution.
A broad big toe (which sometimes deviates outwards).
Beware that this is not an impression caused by shortness of the other toes.
Metatarsals, general abnormalities
Missing metatarsals. Also fusion or accessory epiphyses.
The foot anterior to the navicular is abducted.
This includes everything under 'toes'.
Might be in the spectrum of hypoplastic toes, so use both in the same box.
Use with 'absent' if necessary. Might be a spectrum.
An extra toe or toes on the 5th digit side of the foot. It might just be a nubbin of tissue.
Might be difficult to differentiate from 'hypoplasia'. If this is the case, use both together in the same box.
Blood vessels, general abnormalities
One of the tumours of neural crest origin.
Phosphate depletion for what-ever reason.
All abnormalities of red blood cells. See also acanthocytosis.
Fixed flexion or sometimes extension of multiple joints.
Joints which are stiff, but there are no true contractures.
PRENATAL PROBLEMS, general abnormalities
Very little data on this, but note the ever increasing 'fetal teratogen' syndromes under 'Syndromes'.
Includes polyhydramnios and oligohydramnios.
Use with care, but important if mother is an experienced observer.
small for dates - see BUILD
Use with 'respiratory distress in the neonate' in the same box.
feeding problems - see ABDOMEN
Inability to initiate a task like walking. despite the fact that power and co-ordination in the sitting position are quite normal.
An emotional incontinence. Easily irritated (aroused by a trivial stimulus).
A brief, repetitive, co-ordinated movement such as repetitive blinking, grunting or sniffing.
The involuntary, repetition of words or phrases spoken to the patient by the examiner, often in conjunction with defective comprehension.
Seizures which occur during the first 30 days of life.
Seizures that begin as simple and partial (focal) but which then progress to move to the opposite side with loss of consciousness.
Focal seizures without loss of consciousness.
Also known as dacrystic seizures. These are epileptic seizures in which the patient weeps.
This might be a migraine equivalent, and consists of episodic vomiting (plus photophobia or pallor).
Of no obvious cause.
Bouts of stiffness. Might overlap with 'paroxysmal dystonia' - use together when necessary in the same box.
Involuntary, rhythmic, oscillations of a limb or the whole body at rest. See under 'Extrapyramidal' for 'tremor' - use both in same box when uncertain.
A long head in the anterior-posterior plane (mostly due to premature fusion of the sagittal suture). In scaphocephaly the calvaria is long and narrow. Like the keel of an up-turned boat.

column3: N.III, IV, VI / ophthalmoplegia plus supranuclear
column4: Includes abducens, trochlear and superior oblique palsies or any combination of the three. A conjugate failure of upward gaze and an internuclear ophthalmoplegia (jerk nystagmus in the abducting eye and and failure to adduct the other eye) are included
Mostly a lower motor neuron palsy. Most of the upper motor neuron lesions will be part of a hemiplegia. There is a separate code for a myopathic face under 'muscle'.
ptosis of eye-lids - see EYES (GENERAL)
This is the common jerk nystagmus, but cerebellar nystagmus which might be pendular is included.
Some ataxias in the literature are not typically cerebellar, but use this alone with caution. Rather combine with cerebellar tremor if uncertain.
Weakness on one side of the body. Includes alternating hemiplegia.(first one side, then the other)
Weakness of both lower limbs. Use with, spasticity and brisk reflexes.
All four limb are spastic (more commonly than flaccid) and more or less equally affected. Mostly symmetrical. Use in same box as 'brisk reflexes'.

Symmetrica involuntary movement of the opposite side of the body. If the hand is opened on one side, the other hand opens. All good neurologists tell the story of the sailor climbing a rope to the top of the mast, who turns to wave to his girl friend with one hand.
A slow, writhing, involuntary movement. The word means deprived of a fixed place. Use freely with chorea and dystonia in the same box when they seem to overlap.

Or torsion dystonia. Abnormal fixed, extrapyramidal postures. Almost a more permanent athetosis (unusually slow and persistent). Because these movement types are seldom pure, use with for instance, chorea and athetosis in same box where necessary.

column3: Tremor at rest / postural excl. paroxysmal
column4: Often a pill-rolling rest tremor. Note under 'ataxia' for intention tremor.
Increased muscle tone, not pyramidal, nor extrapyramidal and without evidence of myotonia.

column3: EEG: characteristic pattern of EEG / CN claimed
column4: This includes all typical lesions such as that seen in Angelman's syndrome.
Use for any significant 'white matter change' on neuro-imaging
Poor or absent myelination. Don't use unless the delay in myelination is fairly gross!
Atrophy involving one hemisphere.
Lissencephaly / pachygyria - see NEURORADIOL CONT.
Includes type 1 (the adult form) and type 2 (the infantile type). There is a caudal displacement of the brainstem, cerebellum and more. There might be impaction in the foramen magnum.

An undivided frontal lobe. Might be alobar (a single ventricle, small cerebellum and no lobes), semilobar (the cortex is partially divided in the midline) or even milder, i.e. lobar. Look elsewhere for 'agenesis of the corpus callosum'. Arhinencephaly is the absence of the olfactory tracts.
A split brain, the result of a neuronal migration defect causing the cerebral mantle not to form. Mostly in region of the Sylvan fissure and especially of importance to geneticists if bilateral.
The absence of the thin membrane between the fornix and the corpus callosum. If the corpus callosum is absent, rather use that feature.

A large (and I mean large) reservoir or space behind the transverse fissure of the cerebellum. Seen in conjunction with cerebellar atrophy or hypoplasia. When that is the case use 'cerebellar hemisphere/vermis hypoplasia', in preference.

column3: neonatal brain bleeding - see NEONATAL PROBLEM
column4: neonatal brain bleeding - see NEONATAL PROBLEM
An excess of astroglia in response to a lesion of the CNS. In this case it involves a widespread area of the cerebrum.
Any abnormality (excludes abnormal looking under EM).
The bone is thin, porotic, and will later bow or collapse. Radiologically there is a reduction in density.
Diagosed on X-ray using standard tables showing the age of appearance of the carpal bones, and other ossification centres.
Be careful as there are separate features for hypoplastic humerus, tibia, femur, etc. Use other features with this in the same box where appropriate.
Extra, redundant skin which tends to hang in folds.

A reticulated, bluish mottling of the skin which is common in the newborn and may persist for weeks or months. It is a physiological response to the cold and consists of the dilatation of capillaries and small veins.
Localized fluid retention to severe generalized retention. See also codes for oedema of hands, feet, etc.
They are deep-seated strawberry lesions with little penetration of the overlying skin. They contain large dilated spaces. They are bluish-red with an ill-defined border.
These are benign tumours consisting of mature fat cells.
